description.plain:
“we fell in love in october” is about girl in red and her relationship with another girl. The song is about how they fell in love during fall and Marie’s (girl in red’s) feelings toward her.

In an interview with The Fader, Marie states that there was a lot of drama between the two and that she struggled accepting her. After a while when everything began to settle in, she accepted her and created this song as a tribute.

This song is a prequel to girl in red’s “forget her”, which is about the two breaking up. “we fell in love in october” is girl in red’s most popular song on Spotify to date.

description.plain:
“i wanna be your girlfriend” documents the sentiments that the title implies. Marie (girl in red) laments on her relationship with her friend; ‘Hannah,’ who she has seemingly fallen in love with but who is unaware of this.

The song is a tender confessional for the persona who reveals the details of her unrequited love, further complicated by the stigma and lack of normalised awareness of homosexuality.

The description to the song on girl in red’s bandcamp is simply:

don’t fall in love with a straight girl

annotations:
Oh, Hannah, tell me something nice
 Like flowers and blue skies

Flowers and blue skies, which girl in red is speaking of positively in this song, are signs of spring and summer. However, summer is a mixed bag for girl in red, which she sings about in “summer depression”:

I wanna stay home
Never go outside
Summer depression comes every year
I just want to disappear

Oh, Hannah, I will follow you home
 Although my lips are blue and I’m cold

There are three ways this line could be interpreted– selflessly walking Hannah home to make sure she’s safe, despite the difficulty of the cold; trailing thoughtlessly behind Hannah like a puppy wherever she goes; or following Hannah in an obsessive and potentially creepy way.
It’s unclear which one the singer is talking about– maybe all three at once. Unrequited love is a complicated thing.
Come lie with my bones

There are three interpretations of what this line could mean.

Instead of simply saying “come lie with me”, the narrator uses “bones”. This could imply that if ‘Hannah’ were to lay with the narrator, she would expose her deepest secrets to her. The hard cold truth of a person is often said to be in the bones of them.

She could also be saying that she’ll be dead before Hannah likes her back – it’s near-impossible.

The third is that she loves Hannah so much that she is willing to and wants to die with her.

The look in your eyes
 My hand between your thighs
 Oh, this can’t be real
 It’s all just a dream

Again, these lines of the song tend toward the overtly sexual nature of the singer’s longing. However, these lines differ from previous assertions of such as they shift marginally in perspective – from a daydream to a tangible event occurring in the present.

It details a tender moment wherein romantic progress seems to have been made and the pair are on the brink of moving from their friendship to a physical relationship. However, the narrative voice concludes this thought with a sentiment that leaves the actuality of the event ambiguous.

On one hand, they could be asserted in the lines “This can’t be real, it’s all just a dream” that they are in ecstatic disbelief, or conversely could be more literal – inferring that they can only dream of such.
I wanna kiss you until I lose my breath

Similar to later lyrics in the song, this line deliberates the sexual nature of the persona’s longing; emphasizing their desperation – the culmination of the continually repressed desires of the persona.
I don’t wanna be your friend, I wanna kiss your lips

This line conveys the raw confessional nature of the song; seeming to be akin to the desperate confession of love or an exclamation of a secret they can no longer keep to themselves. It ultimately embodies the somber and desperate state of unrequited longing that the person is in.

It has noticeable similarities to “fallingforyou” by The 1975:

I don’t wanna be your friend
I wanna kiss your neck

description.plain:
“bad idea!” is the last song from girl in red’s debut album BEGINNINGS. It ties up the album with its many callbacks to previous songs. The song references “girls,” “say anything,” and “i need to be alone.”

girl in red sings about being consumed by another person. She regrets the casual sexual relationship she had because she can’t seem to get enough and is now haunted by the feelings.

She premiered the song at the French festival Rock en Seine on August 24th, 2019. The following day she announced via Instagram the song would be released on September 4th, 2019.

annotations: I can’t think straight
She’s referring to her not thinking straight about the events that are happening this night, however, she’s also unable to think STRAIGHT (as in, she’s gay).
[Pre-Chorus]

This last pre-chorus of the song has strong musical similarities to girl in red’s January 2018 song “say anything.”

After the bridge in that song, the chorus repeats one last time, getting more and more intense. The instrumentals build up in a certain rhythm and girl in red intensifies her singing.

In “bad idea!” an identical situation presents itself. Although there are minor differences in instrumentation, the intensification of the last pre-chorus follows the same rhythm and pattern.
“Darling, you’re so pretty, it hurts”

This line is a callback to girl in red’s June 2018 song “girls”, in which the chorus repeats:

They’re so pretty, it hurts
I’m not talking ‘bout boys, I’m talking 'bout girls

In this song, Marie Ulven reverses the line. She is now the one being complimented by someone else.
Was such a bad idea, I need to be alone

This line is a lyrical callback to the chorus of girl in red’s March 2019 song “i need to be alone.” In that song, she sings:

I need to be alone
Or I’m gonna lose my shit

The original song is about being fed up by other people and wanting a bit of peace and quiet. In this song, however, Marie Ulven has a different reason for wanting to be by herself. She isn’t annoyed by other people, but realizes that she’s so infatuated with her love interest that she needs to put a stop to it.

annotations: When your silver is my gold

Both silver & gold are both types of metals, typically used in trophies or medals. Gold usually signifies ‘first place’ in trophies or medals, with silver signifying second place.

Therefore, Red is saying that what their love interest sees as ‘second place’ is ‘first place’ in her eyes. For example, the love interest may see Red as a ‘second choice’ however, Red wants to be a first choice for their love interest.

In this light, I swear I’m blind
 Oh-oh-oh
 In this light, I swear you’re mine

Red has already stated that this song is about a relationship in which the couple are together at night, but never in the day.

In this light, I swear I’m blind

This line suggests that during the daylight, Red pays a lack of attention to their lover – hence being ‘blind.’

In this light, I swear you’re mind

This contrasts with the above line and suggests that during the night time, Red does pay attention to their lover and wants nothing more than for them to be ‘hers’. However, this soon changes as the daylight comes.

description.plain:
In “girls”, Norwegian musician girl in red expresses her sexuality and the conflicts that come from loving girls.

A snippet of the song was played during an Instagram live before it was released as a single on June 8th, 2018; a music video for the song was uploaded to her Youtube channel the same day.

annotations:
Can I tell anyone?
 Afraid of what they’ll say
girl in red likely has social anxiety or fear of losing whatever social image she may have, hence the “Afraid of what they’ll say”
Soft skin and soft lips
Having soft skin and soft lips and distinctly feminine traits. Linking back to her lust for dating girls.

I should be into this guy
 But it’s just a waste of time
 He’s really not my type

Girl In Red recognises that society puts pressure on her to date men and she also puts some onto herself saying “I should be into this guy.” This could be due to internalised homophobia. However, she realises that no matter how hard she tries to fight against her sexuality, she will never be into men, only girls.

I shouldn’t be feeling this
 But it’s too hard to resist

The singer pin points her internalized homophobia : she seems to believe that the attraction she feels for women is something wrong and hence that she should be resisting it – which she can’t because her feelings are too strong to be contained.

I know what I like
 No, this is not a phase
She’s just not into guys and she knows this. People often say that homosexuality is a phase and that those thoughts will eventually fade away but she denies this accusation.
Who I love, who I love, who I love

This repetition, growing louder each time, could represent the freedom she now has to express “who she loves”. After being forced silent for so long, her declaration of loving girls starts quietly, as almost an apology. Soon, it escalates louder and prouder- a statement of “I love who I love, and I won’t let you quiet me anymore.”
I’m acting so strange

This is an important lyric, because it relates to how she is interacting with others amidst such turbulent emotions. It’s very common for someone who is concealing information (especially of this nature) to act differently than usual, because they have developed new understandings and are responding to these realizations. It is usually the most evident between friends in this kind of situation, because it’s possible that the speaker has feelings for them and is afraid to explore such ideas. Thus, this is manifested in behavior that is not akin to their usual self.

Or a coming of age
 This will never change

Another thing homophobic/transphobic parents will say is “It will go away with age.” Girl in red is stating that it will not go away with age and this will never change. She is indeed a lesbian and will most likely be nothing else.
So I push them away

Marie is explaining her internalized homophobia, in that she is so worried that the people close to her wont accept her sexuality. she resorts to pushing these people out of her life, or becoming guarded around them.

’Cause I don’t know what to do
 It’s not like I get to choose who I love

Marie feels conflicted because her heart and head are telling her two different things. On one hand, her heart is telling her that she loves girls, but her brain contradicts this by saying that she’s supposed to love boys. Shamefully, society for the most part looks down on homosexuals. This ‘decision’ to dessent from this expectation is not hers. Marie did not choose this path; she was born to love girls.

description.plain:
“October Passed Me By” serves as a sequel to 2018’s girl in red breakthrough, “we fell in love in october.” It marks Marie’s first release since her 2021 debut album, if i could make it go quiet.

Co-produced with Aaron Dessner, the song centers around a fast-paced acoustic guitar where Marie reminisces about a previous romance. In an interview with Pitchfork, girl in red said of the song:

“October Passed Me By” is where I’m at today, emotionally and musically. Grateful for what has been, and full of love for a very special person that made a huge impact on me as a person.

First announced via an artwork depicting fall leaves posted on social media, girl in red shared the message — “the story continues…” — as well as a joyful picture of herself and Aaron Dessner at the Long Pond studio in upstate New York.

Additionally, “October Passed Me By” was released along with a short film directed by Gustav Johansson, starring Lisa Loven Kongsli and Ruth Vega Fernandez as older versions of the characters from the “we fell in love in october” music video.

annotations: I was busy with the stars, you were looking at me

this calls back to the line in “we fell in love in october,” “looking at the stars, admiring from afar.” though initially this feels like a romantic proclamation of yearning, the singer reflects on it and realizes she was occupied in her idealistic bubble while her partner was trying to be upfront and transparent.

I made you my whole world
 I made you my whole world

The song’s ending directly references the chorus of her 2018’s hit “we fell in love in october,” where Marie was singing:

My girl, my girl, my girl
You will be my girl
My girl, my girl, my girl
You will be my world
My world, my world, my world
You will be my girl

The outro evokes how the singer has centered her life around her former girlfriend, and must now learn to live in a world without her while constantly remembering her: “Always in the back of my mind.”

description.plain:
In “girls”, Norwegian musician girl in red expresses her sexuality and the conflicts that come from loving girls.

A snippet of the song was played during an Instagram live before it was released as a single on June 8th, 2018; a music video for the song was uploaded to her Youtube channel the same day.

annotations:
Can I tell anyone?
 Afraid of what they’ll say
girl in red likely has social anxiety or fear of losing whatever social image she may have, hence the “Afraid of what they’ll say”
Soft skin and soft lips
Having soft skin and soft lips and distinctly feminine traits. Linking back to her lust for dating girls.

I should be into this guy
 But it’s just a waste of time
 He’s really not my type

Girl In Red recognises that society puts pressure on her to date men and she also puts some onto herself saying “I should be into this guy.” This could be due to internalised homophobia. However, she realises that no matter how hard she tries to fight against her sexuality, she will never be into men, only girls.

I shouldn’t be feeling this
 But it’s too hard to resist

The singer pin points her internalized homophobia : she seems to believe that the attraction she feels for women is something wrong and hence that she should be resisting it – which she can’t because her feelings are too strong to be contained.

I know what I like
 No, this is not a phase
She’s just not into guys and she knows this. People often say that homosexuality is a phase and that those thoughts will eventually fade away but she denies this accusation.
Who I love, who I love, who I love

This repetition, growing louder each time, could represent the freedom she now has to express “who she loves”. After being forced silent for so long, her declaration of loving girls starts quietly, as almost an apology. Soon, it escalates louder and prouder- a statement of “I love who I love, and I won’t let you quiet me anymore.”
I’m acting so strange

This is an important lyric, because it relates to how she is interacting with others amidst such turbulent emotions. It’s very common for someone who is concealing information (especially of this nature) to act differently than usual, because they have developed new understandings and are responding to these realizations. It is usually the most evident between friends in this kind of situation, because it’s possible that the speaker has feelings for them and is afraid to explore such ideas. Thus, this is manifested in behavior that is not akin to their usual self.

Or a coming of age
 This will never change

Another thing homophobic/transphobic parents will say is “It will go away with age.” Girl in red is stating that it will not go away with age and this will never change. She is indeed a lesbian and will most likely be nothing else.
So I push them away

Marie is explaining her internalized homophobia, in that she is so worried that the people close to her wont accept her sexuality. she resorts to pushing these people out of her life, or becoming guarded around them.

’Cause I don’t know what to do
 It’s not like I get to choose who I love

Marie feels conflicted because her heart and head are telling her two different things. On one hand, her heart is telling her that she loves girls, but her brain contradicts this by saying that she’s supposed to love boys. Shamefully, society for the most part looks down on homosexuals. This ‘decision’ to dessent from this expectation is not hers. Marie did not choose this path; she was born to love girls.

annotations:
I’m thinking too much again
 How my life will end?
 I have to live tomorrow
 I don’t wanna live tomorrow
Here Girl in Red shows contemplating suicide, and suicidal thoughts, which are keeping her up at night

I’m thinking too much again
 I can’t sleep, it’s 4 AM
 I gotta be somewhere tomorrow
 I don’t wanna go out tomorrow

girl in red begins the song by singing of her difficulty getting to sleep, which is a common symptom of a person having anxiety. Here, she may be speaking of this said anxiety stopping her from falling asleep as she is too busy overthinking.

This is not the first time the singer has referenced her inability to sleep – in her February 2018 song “summer depression,” she sings:

So I stay up all night
Wondering why I’m so tired all the time

Fuck my thoughts
 I think too much
 I think too much
 Fuck my thoughts
 I think too much
 I think too much

When you’re having trouble falling asleep, one of the contributing factors may be that you are overthinking, or that your thoughts spiral out of control. You don’t like it, and recognize that you are thinking too much, but you can’t stop it.

description.plain:
“Summer Depression” is a song released by Girl in Red, initially on Soundcloud, on 16 February 2018.

On the YouTube lyric video, she stated that she isn’t glorifying depression for “Aesthetic” and was just writing a song generated by her own feelings.

annotations: Pretty face with pretty bad dreams

This is referencing the idea that pretty girls (with “pretty faces”) don’t have emotional problems (pretty bad dreams). Many girls struggle with body image issues, insecurities, anxiety, depression, and similar issues, despite what they look like to others.

Waking up feeling like shit
 It’s a normal thing to feel like this

Even though Marie is experiencing multiple mental illnesses, such as depression and social anxiety, she convinces herself that it’s ‘normal.’ She does this to push away her what she’s truly feeling, a common theme in girl in red songs.

De-de-de-depression
 Teenage suicidal
 Why girls?
 Emotional
 Social anxiety

This intro seems to be made up of snippets from radio and TV shows, demonstrating how the world views mental illness as confusing and foreign, especially in girls.

The “why girls?” snippet might also be a reference to girl in red’s sexual orientation, which she’s made multiple songs about.
